radiology_report: A 19-year-old patient presents with a 24-hour history of cough and pharyngeal pain. Low-grade fever in the last few hours. No expectoration. Possible undocumented contact 48 hours ago at a school in Valencia. No dyspnea. Sharp chest pain that worsens with coughing. No urinary syndrome. Lives with parents and one sibling. No ageusia or anosmia. Reports diarrhea with liquid stools, no blood, mucus, or pus. Laboratory results show D-dimer of 1.37 and positive PCR for coronavirus. A non-contrast chest CT scan was performed with optimal study quality. Findings: No significant mediastinal, hilar, internal mammary, or axillary lymphadenopathy. Trachea and main bronchi are normal. Aorta and pulmonary artery are of normal caliber. Cardiac chambers, pericardium, and coronary arteries show no significant abnormalities. Lungs: No infiltrates or other parenchymal lesions. Pleura: No pleural effusion or other abnormalities. Chest wall and thoracic cage: No pathological findings. Abdomen and pelvis: Upper abdominal structures partially included in the lower portion of the study show no significant abnormalities. Conclusion: No significant pathological findings.
layman_report: A 19-year-old patient has had a cough and throat pain for a day and a low fever for a few hours. They haven't coughed up anything and might have been in contact with someone at a school in Valencia two days ago. They don't have trouble breathing or chest pain that gets worse when they cough. They live with their family and don't have a loss of taste or smell. They have had diarrhea with watery stools, but no blood, mucus, or pus. Tests show a slightly high D-dimer level and a positive PCR test for coronavirus. A CT scan of the chest without contrast was done, and it was clear. The results show no swollen lymph nodes in the chest, normal airways, and normal blood vessels. The heart and its covering look fine, and there are no signs of lung infections or other lung problems. There is no fluid around the lungs or other issues. The chest wall and ribcage are normal. The upper belly area, which was partly seen in the scan, looks normal. The conclusion is that there are no significant problems found.

radiology_report: Aspiration pneumonia with asymmetric pulmonary edema.
layman_report: Aspiration pneumonia is a type of lung infection that occurs when you inhale foreign substances like food, liquids, or vomit into your lungs. This can lead to inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs, called pulmonary edema. In this case, the fluid buildup is not the same on both sides of the lungs, which is referred to as asymmetric pulmonary edema.

radiology_report: Technique performed: Non-contrast helical CT of the chest. Transverse reconstructions of 1mm with a lung filter and 1mm with a mediastinal filter. Comparison is made with the study from 01/23/20. Findings: Mediastinum and pulmonary hila: No significant lymphadenopathy. Trachea and main bronchi: No abnormalities. Aorta: Normal size. Pulmonary artery: Normal size (27mm). Cardiac chambers: No significant abnormalities. Coronary arteries: No calcifications. Pericardium: No pericardial effusion or other abnormalities. Sliding hiatal hernia. Lungs: No signs of emphysema. A 6mm nodule in the superior segment of the left lower lobe (image 230) shows no changes since the previous CT and PET-CT. Mosaic perfusion pattern likely due to air trapping. Pleura: No pleural effusion or other abnormalities. Chest wall and thoracic cage: No significant abnormalities. Upper abdominal structures partially included in the lower portion of the study: No significant abnormalities. Conclusion: Mosaic perfusion pattern likely due to air trapping. A 6mm nodule in the superior segment of the left lower lobe shows no changes since the previous study. If stable, the next and final follow-up is advised in 12 months.
layman_report: A special type of chest x-ray called a CT scan was done without using contrast dye. The scan was taken in two different ways to get a good look at the lungs and the middle part of the chest. The results were compared to a scan done on January 23, 2020. Here's what was found: The middle part of the chest and the areas where the lungs connect to the windpipe look normal. The windpipe and the main airways in the lungs are normal. The large blood vessel that carries blood from the heart (aorta) is the right size. The blood vessel that carries blood to the lungs (pulmonary artery) is also the right size (27mm). The heart's chambers look normal. There's no sign of calcium buildup in the blood vessels that supply the heart. The sac around the heart (pericardium) has no fluid or other problems. There's a small hernia where the food pipe goes through the diaphragm. The lungs show no signs of a condition called emphysema. There's a small spot (6mm nodule) in a part of the left lung that hasn't changed since the last CT and PET-CT scans. The scan shows a pattern that might be due to air getting trapped in the lungs. The membranes around the lungs (pleura) are normal with no fluid or other problems. The chest wall and ribcage look normal. Some parts of the upper belly were seen at the bottom of the scan and they look normal too. The main conclusion is that the pattern seen is likely due to air getting trapped in the lungs. The small spot in the left lung hasn't changed, so if it stays the same, the next and final follow-up is advised in 12 months.

layman_report: Thickening is seen around the airways near the center of the lungs, which could be due to inflammation or infection. There is no sign of pneumonia.

Biventricular pacemaker in place. Radiological worsening compared to the X-ray from [date]. These findings do not rule out COVID pneumonia, although they may also occur in the context of congestive heart failure.

The heart appears enlarged, and there's thickening around the lung bases and a mild loss of the normal sharp angle between the lungs and the chest wall. A biventricular pacemaker, a type of heart device, is present. Compared to the X-ray from [date], the situation has worsened. These findings could suggest COVID pneumonia, but they might also be due to heart failure.

radiology_report: A non-contrast chest CT was performed and compared with a previous chest CT study from [date] and PET-CT from [date]. There are no changes in the pleural thickening, which measures 6.6 mm in maximum thickness, and the fibrotic pleuroparenchymal tract with a nodular component and peripheral ground-glass opacity. Two nodules measuring 4 and 6 mm are located in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe, which converge and measure 2.0 x 0.6 cm, previously 2.1 x 0.7 cm on PET-CT from [date]. No other nodules or pulmonary consolidations are identified. There is a severe centrilobular emphysema pattern, predominantly in the upper lobes. Laminar atelectasis is noted in the lingula. No pathological-sized axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes are observed. There is no pleural or pericardial effusion. The thyroid gland is enlarged with intrathoracic extension, unchanged. The upper abdomen is partially included in the study, with no abnormalities on non-contrast CT. No bone or muscular plane abnormalities are observed. Impression: Mixed pseudonodular opacity in the right upper lobe, which may correspond to lepidic growth adenocarcinoma, with no significant changes in size or appearance since the PET-CT from [date]. Follow-up with CT in 12 months is recommended, with a 3-year follow-up according to the Fleischner Society 2017 guidelines.
layman_report: We did a special type of chest X-ray called a non-contrast chest CT and compared it to previous chest CT scans and a PET-CT scan from specific dates. The thickening of the lung covering, which is 6.6 mm at its thickest point, and the scar tissue connecting the lung covering to the lung itself with a small nodule and hazy area at the edges, haven't changed. There are two small lumps in the back part of the right upper lung, one measuring 4 mm and the other 6 mm, which together measure 2.0 x 0.6 cm, previously measured as 2.1 x 0.7 cm on the PET-CT scan from a specific date. No other lumps or areas of lung clumping are seen. There is severe damage to the small air sacs in the lungs, mainly in the upper parts. A thin layer of collapsed lung is noted in a part called the lingula. No swollen lymph nodes in the armpit, chest, or lung area are observed. There is no fluid around the lungs or heart. The thyroid gland is enlarged and extends into the chest, unchanged. The upper belly is partially seen in the study, with no abnormalities on the non-contrast CT. No bone or muscle abnormalities are seen. Conclusion: Mixed nodule-like haziness in the right upper lung, which could be a type of lung cancer that grows along the air sacs, with no significant changes in size or appearance since the PET-CT scan from a specific date. It is recommended to follow up with a CT scan in 12 months, and a 3-year follow-up according to the Fleischner Society 2017 guidelines.

layman_report: The left subclavian central line is in place with its end in the superior vena cava. There are no signs of lung tissue problems. The findings are the same as the previous study with contrast.

radiology_report: The cardiothoracic index is at the upper limit of normal. Prominent hila, likely of vascular etiology.
layman_report: The heart and lung size ratio is at the top of what's considered normal. The areas where the blood vessels enter the lungs are more noticeable, probably because of blood vessel issues.

radiology_report: The trachea is midline. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal and unchanged compared to prior examination. The lungs are clear, without evidence of acute infiltrate or effusion. There is no pneumothorax. The visualized bony structures reveal no acute abnormalities. There is hiatal hernia. No acute cardiopulmonary abnormalities.
layman_report: The windpipe is in the middle. The area around the heart looks normal and hasn't changed since the last check. The lungs are clear, showing no signs of sudden infection or fluid buildup. There's no air outside the lungs. The visible bones don't show any sudden issues. There's a hernia at the opening where the food pipe goes into the stomach. No sudden heart or lung problems.

radiology_report: Suboptimal study due to non-inclusion of the left costophrenic angle. Congested hila. Mild bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates. Infrahilar right interstitial-alveolar infiltrate. The rest shows no significant changes compared to the previous study from yesterday.
layman_report: The x-ray image isn't perfect because it doesn't show the bottom left part of the lungs. The areas where the lungs meet the heart look a bit swollen. There's a bit of fluid around the main airways on both sides. There's also some fluid and inflammation in the lower right part of the lung. Everything else looks the same as the x-ray from yesterday.

radiology_report: Radiologic signs of COPD. Right paratracheal widening suggestive of intrathoracic goiter, with no changes compared to the previous study from October 2016.
layman_report: The imaging shows signs of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). There's an enlargement near the windpipe on the right side that suggests a goiter (enlarged thyroid gland) in the chest, and it hasn't changed since the previous examination in October 2016.

radiology_report: Cardiothoracic findings are of limited pathological significance. Aortic elongation is noted. Calcified granuloma in the left upper lobe. Right diaphragmatic lobulation is observed. No significant radiographic findings are present.
layman_report: The heart and chest area don't show any serious issues. The main blood vessel in the chest is a bit longer than normal. There's a hardened lump in the left upper part of the lung. The muscle under the right lung is a bit irregular. There are no important findings from the x-ray.

radiology_report: Volume loss in the right hemithorax with pleural calcifications and secondary changes suggestive of probable tuberculous origin pachypleuritis. Cardiomegaly. Aortic elongation. Comparison with the previous study dated 11 03 2011 shows no significant changes.
layman_report: The right side of the chest has less volume, with calcium deposits on the lung lining and related changes that suggest a likely tuberculosis-related thickening of the lung lining. The heart is enlarged. The main blood vessel is stretched out. Compared to the previous test from November 3, 2011, there are no significant changes.

radiology_report: No foci of pulmonary consolidation or significant pleural effusion are observed. Subtle, nonspecific bibasal pulmonary reticular opacities are noted.
layman_report: There are no areas of the lungs that have become solid or significant fluid buildup around the lungs. However, there are some faint, nonspecific patterns in the lower parts of both lungs that are not clear.

radiology_report: Massive right pleural effusion with a small air collection in the left lateral decubitus position without contralateral displacement of mediastinal structures, suggesting the likely presence of underlying lung collapse.
layman_report: There is a large amount of fluid on the right side of the chest and a small air pocket on the left side. The structures in the middle of the chest are not pushed to the other side, which suggests that there might be a part of the lung that has collapsed.

radiology_report: No radiographic changes.
layman_report: There are no visible changes on the x-ray.

radiology_report: Technique: Thoracoabdominopelvic CT with intravenous contrast. Findings: Compared to the previous study performed approximately 4 months ago on 27 2 2020. Thorax: No pulmonary nodules suspicious for malignancy are observed. No pleural effusion. No hilar or mediastinal lymph nodes of pathological size or appearance are noted. Venous catheter with distal end in the superior vena cava and right atrium. Abdomen and Pelvis: Post-surgical changes in the colonic framework are observed, with colonic anastomosis at the level of the right hypochondrium and flank, and rectosigmoid anastomosis, with a decrease in post-surgical inflammatory changes and no signs of local recurrence. Liver, biliary tract, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands, kidneys, and minimally distended bladder show no significant abnormalities. The gallbladder is not visualized, likely collapsed or the patient may have undergone cholecystectomy; this should be correlated with the patient's history. No mesenteric, retroperitoneal, iliac, or inguinal lymph nodes of pathological size or appearance are noted. No free intra-abdominal fluid. No bone lesions suspicious for malignancy are observed. Conclusion: No signs of local, nodal, or distant recurrence are observed.
layman_report: We used a special CT scan technique to take pictures of the chest, belly, and pelvis with a contrast dye. Compared to the scan done about 4 months ago on February 27, 2020, here's what we found: In the chest area, there are no suspicious lung lumps that might be cancer. There's no fluid around the lungs. We don't see any swollen lymph nodes in the chest area that look like they could be a problem. There's a tube in a big vein that goes into the upper chest vein and the right side of the heart. In the belly and pelvis area, we can see some changes from past surgeries on the large intestine. There's a connection where the large intestine was joined together in the upper right part of the belly and the side, and another connection in the lower part of the large intestine. The手术后的炎症减少了, and there are no signs of the problem coming back in that area. The liver, bile ducts, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands, kidneys, and the slightly filled-up bladder all look normal. We can't see the gallbladder, maybe it's collapsed or the patient had it removed; we should check the patient's history. There are no swollen lymph nodes in the belly area that look like they could be a problem. There's no free fluid in the belly. There are no bone problems that look like they could be cancer. Overall, we don't see any signs that the cancer has come back locally, in the lymph nodes, or somewhere else far away.

radiology_report: Thickening of the left fissure with associated pleuroparenchymal tract. No relevant findings.
layman_report: The left lung's dividing line has thickened, causing a connection between the lung tissue and the pleura. There are no other significant issues.

radiology_report: Radiologic signs of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
layman_report: The x-ray shows signs of a long-term lung condition called chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

layman_report: There are no significant abnormal findings. There is no sign of lung tissue infiltration or consolidation.

radiology_report: Comparison with the previous study dated 07 06 2010. Healed fractures of the left costal arches. Dorsolumbar scoliosis. No significant changes compared to the previous study.
layman_report: Comparing to the imaging study done on July 6, 2010, the fractures in the left rib area have healed. There is a curve in the lower back. There are no major changes compared to the previous study.

radiology_report: No signs of pneumothorax. Pacemaker with catheter tip in the right ventricle. Radiological signs of COPD. Cardiomegaly.
layman_report: There are no indications of a collapsed lung. There is a pacemaker with a tube ending in the right lower heart chamber. There are X-ray signs of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), which is a group of lung diseases. The heart appears enlarged.

radiology_report: No signs of pulmonary tuberculosis.
layman_report: There are no indications of lung infection caused by tuberculosis.

radiology_report: The mediastinum shows no evidence of adenopathy or masses. Cardiomegaly is present, along with coronary and aortic root calcifications. There is bilateral pleural effusion, predominantly on the left, with partial passive atelectasis of the left lower lobe. Subsegmental atelectasis is noted in the left lung base. No nodular lesions are observed in the visualized lung parenchyma. Splenomegaly and free intra-abdominal fluid are present.
layman_report: The area between the lungs, called the mediastinum, doesn't show any swollen lymph nodes or masses. The heart is enlarged, and there are calcium deposits in the heart's blood vessels and the main blood vessel leaving the heart. There is fluid buildup on both sides of the lungs, more on the left, and part of the left lower lung is not fully expanded. A small part of the left lung base is also not fully expanded. No round abnormal growths are seen in the lung tissue. The spleen is enlarged, and there is fluid in the abdominal cavity.

radiology_report: The heart is of normal size, and the cardiomediastinal contours are normal. The lungs are hyperinflated but clear, with no discrete focal consolidation to suggest pneumonia. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Impression: No radiographic evidence of pneumonia.
layman_report: The heart is the right size, and everything around the heart looks normal. The lungs are a bit overinflated but clear, with no specific areas of clumping that would suggest pneumonia. There is no fluid around the lungs or air outside the lungs. Conclusion: There is no X-ray sign of pneumonia.

layman_report: There are no important findings seen on the radiology images.

radiology_report: Posteroanterior chest radiograph without relevant pathological findings.
